position.marginalia_text: Obserua semper peritissima scientiaru[m]: subtiliss[im]a Experimentorum: potentissima actionum.

marginalia.translation: Always observe the most expert examples of science, the most subtle examples of experimentation, and the most potent examples of action.

position.marginalia_text: Quorsum tot libri, et tanta studia, si non plus possunt doctores, quàm illiterati?

marginalia.translation: What is the point so many books and so many studies, if teachers can do no more than illiterate men?

position.marginalia_text: Medice, cura teipsum. Ante omnia, Nosce teipsu[m].

marginalia.translation: Doctor, heal thyself. Before everything, know thyself.
The greatest theurge and panurge of the world.

position.marginalia_text: Qui se habet, nil perdidit: Ausus est dicere Seneca.

marginalia.translation: Whoever has himself can lose nothing. Seneca dared to speak.
Even the most powerful things are less powerful than the powerful man.

position.marginalia_text: Totum in se habet, qui se habet: Ausus est dicere Cassiodorus. Quod petis, intùs habes.

marginalia.translation: Whoever has himself has everything in himself. Cassiodorus dared to speak. Whatever you desire, you shall have within.

position.marginalia_text: et ipsis A[e]gyptijs operabatur peritiùs: et omnibus Magis potentiora Miracula perpetrabat.

marginalia.translation: and worked more skillfully than the Egyptians themselves, and carried out miracles more powerful than all the wise men.

position.marginalia_text: Hominum scripta, errantes planeta[e]: Artiu[m], et Virtutum impressiones, fixa[e] stella[e].

marginalia.translation: The writings of men are wandering planes; the articulation of the Arts and Virtues are fixed stars.

position.marginalia_text: Florescat ars: virescat virtus: splendescat vir. Nunq[uam] languidus.

marginalia.translation: Art flourishes, virtue prospers, man begins to shine. Never languid.
